english_translation: Narrated by Abu Talha al-Ansari: He recited Surah al-Tawbah until he reached the verse 'Go forth, light-armed and heavy-armed, and strive with your wealth and your selves in the way of Allah' (9:41). He said: It seems we are being called upon, young and old. My sons, prepare me. They said: O father, you have already fought with the Messenger of Allah ﷺ, and with Abu Bakr and Umar, so we shall fight for you. He refused, so they prepared him and he went out to sea, and he died in the sea. They did not find an island to bury him in for seven days, and he did not decompose.

narrators.name: Hammad ibn Salamah
narrators.full_name: Hammad ibn Salamah ibn Dinar al-Azdi al-Basri

narrators.name: Anas ibn Malik
narrators.full_name: Anas ibn Malik ibn al-Nadr al-Ansari al-Khazraji

narrators.name: Abu Talha al-Ansari
narrators.full_name: Zayd ibn Sahl ibn al-Aswad al-Ansari al-Khazraji
reliabilityIssues: Ambiguous transmission term 'anna' may indicate indirect connection

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: Use of 'anna' (أَنَّ) with Abu Talha introduces ambiguity in transmission - could indicate indirect narration
Hammad ibn Salamah has noted issues with occasional errors in his narrations

potential_issues.issue: Use of 'anna' (أَنَّ) in reporting from Abu Talha
potential_issues.impact: While 'anna' is used in establishing narratives, it can indicate indirect transmission. However, given that Anas ibn Malik is a reliable source and the chain is otherwise strong, this does not significantly undermine authenticity, though it suggests the hadith describes events rather than direct speech.

potential_issues.issue: Hammad ibn Salamah's narrations contain occasional errors
potential_issues.impact: Hammad is generally reliable (Thiqah) but has been noted to have some awham (errors/confusions) in certain narrations. This requires careful evaluation of the hadith's authenticity.

Topics: Incident of Abu Talha responding to the call for jihad
Dialogue between Abu Talha and his sons regarding military expedition
Death of a companion during maritime journey
Preservation of a body at sea without decomposition

english_translation: Narrated by Abu Talha al-Ansari: Verily the Prophet ﷺ when he conquered a people, he would stay in their settlement for three days. When he conquered the people of Badr, he commanded twenty-seven of the chiefs of Quraysh to be thrown into a well from the wells of Badr, a foul and evil well. On the third day, he commanded his camel to be saddled and mounted it, then walked until he stood at the edge of the well and called out to them: O so-and-so son of so-and-so, would it please you that you had obeyed Allah and His Messenger? Verily we have found what our Lord promised us to be true. Have you found what your Lord promised you to be true? Umar said: O Messenger of Allah, are you speaking to bodies without souls? The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: You are not more hearing of what I say than they are.

narrators.name: Qatadah ibn Di'amah
reliabilityIssues: Known for tadlis (concealment of weaknesses) especially in narrations from Anas

narrators.name: Anas ibn Malik
narrators.full_name: Anas ibn Malik ibn al-Nadr al-Ansari al-Khazraji

narrators.name: Abu Talha al-Ansari
narrators.full_name: Zayd ibn Sahl ibn al-Aswad al-Ansari al-Khazraji

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: Presence of Said ibn Bishr who is classified as Da'if (weak)
Qatadah is a known mudallis (category 3) narrating from Anas using 'an, which requires caution
Weak link in the chain from Abu Bakr ibn Khalad whose reliability is limited

potential_issues.issue: Said ibn Bishr (Hafas ibn Jumai) is a weak narrator (Da'if)
potential_issues.impact: This significantly weakens the chain. Said ibn Bishr is known for errors and is classified as weak by hadith scholars. This is a critical weakness in the transmission.

potential_issues.issue: Qatadah is a mudallis (category 3) narrating from Anas using 'an
potential_issues.impact: Qatadah's use of 'an (indirect transmission) in narrations from Anas is problematic as he practiced tadlis. Direct narration from Qatadah requires caution. This affects the chain's reliability.

potential_issues.issue: Abu Bakr ibn Khalad's limited reliability information
potential_issues.impact: The first narrator in this chain has limited established reliability, which compounds the already weak chain below him.

Topics: Battle of Badr and aftermath
Incident of the Prophet ﷺ addressing fallen enemies at the well
Dialogue between Umar and the Prophet ﷺ about speaking to the dead
The Prophet's ﷺ practice of staying in conquered settlements for three days

english_translation: Narrated by Abu Talha al-Ansari: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: 'The angels, peace be upon them, do not enter a house in which there is a dog, nor a picture.'

chainIssues: Ibn Shihab al-Zuhri is a mudallis but highly reliable - his use of 'an does not significantly affect the chain as he is one of the most dependable narrators

potential_issues.issue: Ibn Shihab al-Zuhri is a known mudallis (category 2-3) narrating from Ubaydullah using 'an
potential_issues.impact: While Ibn Shihab al-Zuhri is classified as a mudallis, he is simultaneously one of the most reliable narrators in hadith sciences. His mudallisun nature does not significantly impact this chain given his overwhelming reliability and the strong backing of other narrators in the chain. Scholars generally accept his narrations even with 'an transmission.

Topics: Prohibition of angels entering houses with dogs
Prohibition of angels entering houses with pictures or statues
Restriction of angelic presence based on forbidden items

english_translation: Narrated by Abu Talha al-Ansari: I heard the Messenger of Allah ﷺ saying: 'The angels, peace be upon them, do not enter a house in which there is a dog, nor an idol.'

chainIssues: Multiple weak and very weak narrators in the chain
Sahl ibn Abi Salih (Dinar ibn Umar) is classified as Da'if Jiddan (very weak)
Wahban is Layyin al-Hadith (weak in hadith)

potential_issues.issue: Sahl ibn Abi Salih (actually Dinar ibn Umar al-Asadi) is classified as Da'if Jiddan (very weak)
potential_issues.impact: This narrator is among the weakest categories. He has been labeled as 'Rafidah' (Shia extremist sect), indicating potential bias and unreliability in transmission.

potential_issues.issue: Said ibn Yasir al-Ansari is Majhul (unknown)
potential_issues.impact: Unknown narrators weaken the chain. With only limited or no information about reliability, this creates a significant gap in the chain of transmission.

potential_issues.issue: Multiple weak narrators in succession (Wahban, Khalid)
potential_issues.impact: The accumulation of weak narrators at the beginning of the chain severely compromises the hadith's authenticity.

Topics: Prohibition of angels entering houses with dogs
Prohibition of angels entering houses with idols or statues
Abu Talha's direct hearing from the Prophet ﷺ

english_translation: Narrated by Abu Lubabah: When the Messenger of Allah ﷺ was pleased with him (after his repentance), he said: Verily, from my repentance is that I abandon the house of my people, and dwell with you in your house, and I give away my wealth as charity to Allah and His Messenger. He said: One-third is sufficient for you.
